<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 332, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 185, 905, 200]]<|/det|>
0625/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 207, 905, 222]]<|/det|>
May/June 2019  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 228, 905, 242]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 589, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 235, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 764, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 564, 630, 579]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 99, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 606, 89]]<|/det|>
A digital stop-clock measures time in minutes and seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 730, 120]]<|/det|>
The stop-clock reads 00:50 when it is started (i.e. 00 minutes 50 seconds).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 391, 149]]<|/det|>
It reads 02:10 when it is stopped.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 161, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
What is the shortest possible time that has elapsed between starting and stopping the stop-clock?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 205, 134, 223]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 205, 327, 223]]<|/det|>
1 minute 20 seconds

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 232, 134, 250]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 232, 336, 250]]<|/det|>
2 minutes 00 seconds

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 257, 134, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 257, 336, 275]]<|/det|>
2 minutes 10 seconds

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 282, 134, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 282, 336, 301]]<|/det|>
3 minutes 00 seconds

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 327, 97, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 714, 345]]<|/det|>
A long-distance runner wishes to calculate her average speed for a race.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 357, 405, 375]]<|/det|>
Which calculation should she use?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 388, 134, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 384, 415, 415]]<|/det|>
average speed = \(\frac{\text{total distance}}{\text{total time}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 425, 134, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 425, 504, 444]]<|/det|>
average speed = total distance \(\times\) total time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 459, 134, 478]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 459, 415, 488]]<|/det|>
average speed = \(\frac{\text{total time}}{\text{total distance}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 497, 134, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 497, 504, 515]]<|/det|>
average speed = total distance + total time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> A heavy metal ball falls vertically downwards through air past four equally spaced levels J, K, L and M. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 112, 636, 285]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 298, 638, 317]]<|/det|> The times taken to fall from one level to the next are measured. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 667, 348]]<|/det|> Where is the speed of the ball greatest and which time is shortest? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 359, 531, 504]]<|/det|>
speed is
greatest between		time is
shortest between
AJ and KJ and K
BJ and KL and M
CL and MJ and K
DL and ML and M

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 665, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 131, 205, 149]]<|/det|>

temperature of liquidmolecules escape from

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 408, 241]]<|/det|>
The metal surface of a kettle is hot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 885, 271]]<|/det|>
What happens to the cool air outside the kettle when it comes into contact with the hot kettle?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|> A student measures the level of radiation emitted from a radioactive substance. He places a detector very close to the substance. He puts different absorbers between the radioactive substance and the detector. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 128, 781, 266]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 280, 828, 299]]<|/det|> The student's results are shown. These results are corrected for background radiation. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 310, 702, 457]]<|/det|>
absorbercounter reading counts per minute
none95
thin paper52
few mm of aluminium52
several cm of lead12
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 467, 623, 488]]<|/det|> Which types of radiation are being emitted by the substance? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 497, 134, 515]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 497, 408, 515]]<|/det|> \(\alpha\) -particles and \(\beta\) -particles only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 524, 134, 543]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 524, 371, 543]]<|/det|> \(\alpha\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 552, 134, 570]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 552, 371, 570]]<|/det|> \(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 579, 133, 598]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 579, 428, 598]]<|/det|> \(\alpha\) -particles, \(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 623, 104, 640]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 623, 818, 641]]<|/det|> The nuclei of the atoms in a substance are changing randomly and emitting radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 653, 425, 672]]<|/det|> What is happening to the substance? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 682, 131, 700]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 682, 500, 700]]<|/det|> It is undergoing electromagnetic induction. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 708, 131, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 708, 406, 726]]<|/det|> It is undergoing magnetisation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 735, 131, 752]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 735, 393, 752]]<|/det|> It is undergoing solidification. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 761, 133, 778]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 761, 437, 778]]<|/det|> It is undergoing radioactive decay.
